Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was in the supermarket with my son, trying to pick up groceries before my afternoon shift at the construction site. He darted away from me, weaving between carts and displays, laughing as he went. I felt the eyes of other shoppers on me, expecting me to step in, to teach him discipline and respect for public spaces. I called his name, my voice sharp, but he only giggled louder. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from the site: “Evacuation alarm, all staff must report to muster point now.” My heart pounded. I knew the rules: when the alarm sounds, you drop everything and go, no exceptions. My team was counting on me to be there, to follow protocol, to keep everyone safe. But here I was, torn between chasing after my son to correct his behavior and rushing to the site as a responsible worker. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. I stood frozen, caught between the expectations of a good mother and a reliable laborer, unsure which way to turn.
